Award.AwardTitle: Metamorphic and Tectonic Evolution of the Tethyan Himalaya, Central Nepal
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, new petrologic methods are being developed to help constrain the pressure-temperature-time evolution of metamorphic rocks of the Tethyan Himalayan Sequence exposed in central Nepal. These rocks are key lithologies for understanding the early history of the Himalayan orogen and for testing tectonic models, but their calcareous compositions have defied previous petrologic and chronologic efforts. Recent petrologic advances, however, indicate that titanite major element, trace element (Zr), and U-Pb isotope geochemistry can simultaneously constrain pressure, temperature and age of formation. Titanite is extremely common in Himalayan calcareous rocks. Crystals exhibit chemically and chronologically distinct sub-grain domains and preserve crystallization conditions to temperatures of about 800 Â°C. By determining pressure-temperature-time conditions for these different domains, we can for the first time map out the pressure-temperature-time evolution of these rocks. These data will discriminate among models of collisional orogenesis, particularly the degree to which the middle and lower crust flows plastically, and may provide a unique window into the early tectonic history of the Himalaya. Results will also broadly impact investigations of igneous petrogenesis and ages and histories of hydrothermal and ore systems. All data will be permanently archived with MetPetDB.

This research addresses several fundamental problems of how continental crust behaves during plate collisions, especially the degree to which the middle and lower crust flows plastically, and how extensional systems, which thin the crust, can form when the overall forces should cause thickening. Our work will also develop new interpretational methods that will advance research in igneous, hydrothermal and ore-forming processes. In addition to the research goals of the project, a two to three day workshop will be held at Tribhuvan University in Kathmandu to help train Nepalese scientists in analytical and interpretational methods and how these data can be used to discriminate among competing hypotheses. This work will also support the research and training of a new PhD student as well as an undergraduate, who we will seek to recruit from Boise State University?s LSAMP program. The PI leverages educational opportunities in his undergraduate and graduate courses at Boise State University, which reaches a different student demographic than other American universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop methods of analyzing trace minerals, especially titanite, for investigating the history of the India-Asia collision in central Nepal. The South Tibetan Detachment System (STDS), a major extensional fault at the crest of the Himalaya, may hold the key to understanding either the early history of thickening or the dynamics of extensional thinning during collision (or both). Our work exploits both the temperature and age usefulness of titanite, which helps us discriminate among competing models for the early history of the Himalaya.

Our primary results are that temperatures in the Marsyandi rocks are high, c. 700-800 °C, and show consistent trends within rocks from similar areas. Temperature-time histories separate according to 3 structural levels, and are inconsistent with extensional throw along the mapped ductile STDS. Rather, titanite data indicate a long-lived thrust at this structural level, but that rocks cooled as a block. These data suggest that the mapped STDS does not actually exist in this area. Although some local extensional shear is possible late in the tectonic evolution of the region, rocks are better interpreted simply as GHS rocks, whose metamorphic evolution is defined almost entirely by thrust tectonics. These data provide further evidence for multiple thrust sense shear zones within the Greater Himalayan Sequence (GHS), and support the concept that the GHS was assembled through a series of thrusts, rather than as a coherently flowing ductile channel.

Additional related research include the following 5 results:

(1) We find little evidence for extensional shear in the Galchhi region. Extensional but also thrust-sense characteristics are well represented, so textures cannot be assigned unambiguously to extension alone. Zircon ages are most consistent with an intra-GHS thrust, similar to other intra-GHS thrusts mapped elsewhere in the region and perhaps throughout the orogen, e.g. as we have found in the Marsyandi area.

(2) The Askot klippe in northern India clearly belongs to the Lesser Himalayan Sequence (LHS), and thus represents an intra-LHS thrust – the Munsiari thrust. These rocks have been proposed to have formed in an arc, and an economic sulfide deposit there probably reflects this origin or possibly within a later local extensional system.

(3) Zircon is predicted to grow mainly upon cooling and exhumation, because Zr contents of metamorphic minerals (particularly garnet and hornblende) release Zr with decreasing temperature  and because melts dissolve a disproportionate amount of Zr. Many metamorphic zircon ages reported as dating ultra-high pressure conditions actually reflect late-stage cooling and melt crystallization.

(4) a new review of titanite petrochronology emphasizes its resistance to diffusional resetting of Pb and Zr, so it retains temperature information and ages to very high temperatures, c. 800 °C. Sector zoning, which is a crystallographically controlled phenomenon, is an important consideration. Ironically the most precise ages (least common Pb) correspond with anomalously high Zr (least accurate temperatures). Careful characterization of titanite sectors is crucial to accurate retrieval of temperature-time histories.

(5) A new review of diffusion in the context of research that integrates petrology and geochronology emphasizes the large uncertainties that accrue in using diffusion profiles to recover temperature-time histories. Some inconsistencies between experimental and empirical constraints on diffusivities provide new avenues for research and generally imply that rocks record pressure-temperature-time conditions to higher temperature than experiments imply. The chemistry of mineral overgrowths (e.g. titanite around rutile) may provide new insights into petrogenesis and temperature-time evolution.

This work supported the research activities and trining of graduate student Jesse Walters, post-doctoral researcher Stacey Corrie, and undergraduate student Christopher Markley. Walters and PI Kohn continued to receive training and practical experience collecting Raman confocal data using a new instrument installed in the Materials Science Department. PhD student Walters has also been further trained in microanalysis of zircon, titanite and rutile for trace element thermometry and U-Pb geochronology, and can now collect data independently. He has also been trained in data reduction procedures using Iolite commercial software, and has taken on a role helping mentor undergraduate students collecting similar data investigating metamorphic evolution of rocks from Santa Catalina Island, California. A Reviews in Mineralogy and Geochemistry volume and associated chapters have help weld collaborative ties between the PI and researchers at the University of Bern and at University of Maryland.

All work has been presented at meetings, and is published, accepted for publication, or in review. Walters' material on the Marsyandi rocks was presented at fall AGU 2015, his MS thesis was finalized in spring 2016, and his work is currently in review for publication. This research has resulted in publication of 1 MS thesis, 1 book, 1 chapter in a book, 10 journal articles published or accepted for publication (1 still in review), and 9 presentations at international meetings.
